data.title: Re Tugor Khan
data.text:
On 12 May 1998 18:20:30 -0700, leov...@iinet.net.au (Leo van de Pas) wrote:

>Dear Havard, I cannot tell you details about Tugor, only that according >to

ES your tree is slightly wrong. I am not sure whether he was Khan >of the

Cumans at Polowsk or Khan of Polowsk----- > > Tugor Khan of the Cumans >

I > Elene Polovetskaja-=-Svjatopolk II Grand Duke of Kiev 1093-1113

> I > Sbislava of Kiev-=-Boleslaw III

Krzywousty King of Poland > >Polovetskaja is an

interesting indication to Polowsk. >Hope this helps,

Tugor, Khan of the Cumans, may possibly be the same person as Togortak, one of

the Cuman chiefs. Anna Comnena refers to him in "The Alexiad": (Penguin

Transl,), p. 253: "In the Cuman army there were numerous chiefs, but the

outstanding leaders were Togortak, Maniak and some others noted for their

warlike qualities." p. 302: " ... the Cumans. Marianus Mavrocatacalon caught

sight of Togortak, their commander-in-chief, and armed with a long spear

charged against him at full gallop. He would almost undoubtedly have killed

him, had not his Cuman bodyguard rescued him in time ..."

This Cuman war took place around 1094. The Cumans were also called Polovetsans,

which may account for the confusion with Polowsk. They were a Turk nomad tribe

allied to the Kiev Russians, so it would make excellent political sense for

Svjatopolk to marry a daughter of one of their most powerful khans.

As an interesting sideline, the opera "Prince Igor" by Borodin, with the

well-known "Polovetsan Dances", is written over a libretto (of doubtful

historicity) about the conflicts between Russians and Polovetsans/Cumans at

those times. History says nothing about Togortak/Tugor Khan's abilities as

dancer ... :-)

Kåre A. Lie -------------------------------------------------------- Things

are not as they are seen, nor are they otherwise.

______Does anyone have any information on what became of the Cumans, I seem to

recall reading something that said they ended up in Hungary and that there is

still an ethnic group in existance who claim descent from them.?

Does anyone know of other mailing lists which specialise in medieval European

history. ? _______________________

John....@snl.co.uk

KHF333 wrote:

>

> In a message dated 5/14/98 7:50:11 AM, you wrote:

>

> <<Kuthen's daughter, Elisabeth, in 1254 married Stephen V who, in 1270,

> became King of Hungary. They had (at least) six children and their

> descendants are to be found all over the world>>

>

> Is it likely that any of these married into Western Eurpopean royal lines?

> This is an interesting connection.
